# Patellar reflex

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Patellar_tendon_reflex_arc.png/220px-
Patellar_tendon_reflex_arc.png)](/wiki/File:Patellar_tendon_reflex_arc.png)

[](/wiki/File:Patellar_tendon_reflex_arc.png "Enlarge")

Schematic representation of patellar tendon reflex (knee jerk) pathway

The **patellar reflex** or **knee-jerk** (myotatic) (monosynaptic) (American
spelling **knee reflex**)[1] is a [stretch reflex](/wiki/Stretch_reflex
"Stretch reflex") which tests the L2, L3, and L4 segments of the [spinal
cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord").[2]

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Mechanism
  * 2 Purpose of testing
  * 3 History
  * 4 In popular culture
  * 5 See also
  * 6 Notes
  * 7 References

## Mechanism[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Patellar_reflex&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Mechanism")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/99/Question_book-new.svg/50px-Question_book-new.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Question_book-new.svg) |  This section **does not[cite](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources "Wikipedia:Citing sources") any [sources](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")**. Please help [improve this section](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Patellar_reflex&action=edit) by [adding citations to reliable sources](/wiki/Help:Introduction_to_referencing_with_Wiki_Markup/1 "Help:Introduction to referencing with Wiki Markup/1"). Unsourced material may be challenged and [removed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability#Burden_of_evidence "Wikipedia:Verifiability"). _(April 2016)_ _([Learn how and when to remove this template message](/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_  
---|---  
  
Striking the [patellar tendon](/wiki/Patellar_tendon "Patellar tendon") with a
[reflex hammer](/wiki/Reflex_hammer "Reflex hammer") just below the
[patella](/wiki/Patella "Patella") stretches the [muscle
spindle](/wiki/Muscle_spindle "Muscle spindle") in the [quadriceps
muscle](/wiki/Quadriceps_muscle "Quadriceps muscle"). This produces a signal
which travels back to the spinal cord and synapses (without interneurons) at
the level of L3 in the spinal cord, completely independent of higher centres.
From there, an [alpha motor neuron](/wiki/Alpha_motor_neuron "Alpha motor
neuron") conducts an efferent impulse back to the [quadriceps femoris
muscle](/wiki/Quadriceps_femoris_muscle "Quadriceps femoris muscle"),
triggering contraction. This contraction, coordinated with the relaxation of
the antagonistic flexor hamstring muscle causes the leg to kick. This is a
reflex of proprioception which helps maintain [posture](/wiki/Neutral_spine
"Neutral spine") and [balance](/wiki/Balance_\(ability\) "Balance
\(ability\)"), allowing to keep one's balance with little effort or conscious
thought.

The patellar reflex is a clinical and classic example of the monosynaptic
[reflex arc](/wiki/Reflex_arc "Reflex arc"). There is no
[interneuron](/wiki/Interneuron "Interneuron") in the pathway leading to
contraction of the quadriceps muscle. Instead, the bipolar sensory neuron
synapses directly on a motor neuron in the spinal cord. However, there _is_ an
inhibitory interneuron used to relax the antagonistic hamstring muscle
([Reciprocal innervation](/wiki/Reciprocal_innervation "Reciprocal
innervation")).

This test of a basic automatic reflex may be influenced by the patient
consciously inhibiting or exaggerating the response; the doctor may use the
[Jendrassik maneuver](/wiki/Jendrassik_maneuver "Jendrassik maneuver") as a
distraction or diversion in order to ensure a more valid reflex test.

## Purpose of
testing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Patellar_reflex&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Purpose of testing")]

After the tap of a hammer, the leg is normally extended once and comes to
rest. The absence or decrease of this reflex is problematic, and known as
[Westphal's sign](/wiki/Westphal%27s_sign "Westphal's sign"). This reflex may
be diminished or absent in [lower motor neuron
lesions](/wiki/Lower_motor_neuron_lesion "Lower motor neuron lesion") and
during sleep. On the other hand, multiple oscillation of the leg (pendular
reflex) following the tap may be a sign of [cerebellar
diseases](/wiki/Cerebellar_diseases "Cerebellar diseases"). Exaggerated
(brisk) deep tendon reflexes such as this can be found in [upper motor neuron
lesions](/wiki/Upper_motor_neuron_lesion "Upper motor neuron lesion"),
[hyperthyroidism](/wiki/Hyperthyroidism "Hyperthyroidism")[3], anxiety or
nervousness. The test itself assesses the nervous tissue between and including
the L2 and L4 segments of the spinal cord.[2]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Patellar_reflex&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: History")]

The term _knee-jerk_ was recorded by Sir [Michael
Foster](/wiki/Michael_Foster_\(physiologist\) "Michael Foster
\(physiologist\)") in his Textbook of [physiology](/wiki/Physiology
"Physiology") in 1877: "Striking the tendon below the patella gives rise to a
sudden extension of the leg, known as the knee-jerk."[4]

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Patellar_reflex&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: In popular culture")]

The term began to be used figuratively from the early 20th century onwards.
[O. O. McIntyre](/wiki/O._O._McIntyre "O. O. McIntyre"), in his New York Day-
By-Day column in [The Coshocton Tribune](/wiki/The_Coshocton_Tribune "The
Coshocton Tribune"), October 1921, wrote: "Itinerant preacher stemming
Broadway on a soap box. And gets only an occasional knee-jerk."[4]

qa.question: state the type of stimulus that would cause a knee jerk reflex to occur

nq_6620_6.Answer Analysis: The answer specifies that striking the tendon below the patella is the stimulus that causes a knee jerk reflex.
